feature: Early stable baseline (Sample 0, Sample 4, Sample 15, Sample 93) - occurrence: roughly t=0..45 (varies sample-to-sample). Manifestation: low-amplitude, slowly-varying positive level around +0.5 (small Gaussian jitter). Time-frequency: very low energy concentrated at the 0Hz row and adjacent lowest-frequency rows. Heatmap mapping: predominantly weak-to-moderate red in the lowest frequency rows around the early window in most samples (indicating the model views this stable offset as a typical baseline feature). Interpretation: typical feature (red at 0Hz row), with only scattered blue pixels in higher adjacent frequencies (minor atypical contributions).

Short-duration positive impulse / spike (Sample 0: t≈55-62; Sample 4: t≈60-68; Sample 15: t≈95-102; Sample 93: t≈100-108) - occurrence: narrow time window. Manifestation: very sharp, large positive peak with amplitude up to ≈ +3.5–+4.0 above baseline (fast rise then immediate fall). Time-frequency: a concentrated high-energy patch appearing in the lowest frequency rows and spilling slightly into adjacent low-frequency rows; sometimes a narrow spread to intermediate frequencies if any jitter present. Heatmap mapping: strong red concentrated at the 0Hz row and adjacent low-frequency rows for the spike time window (consistent across samples) → classified as a typical, discriminative feature by the model. Some sparse blue pixels sometimes appear in higher frequency rows at the same time window (minor atypical components), but red dominates.

Immediate deep negative valley following the spike (Sample 0: t≈62-90; Sample 4: t≈70-95; Sample 15: t≈102-130; Sample 93: t≈110-140) - occurrence: immediately after the spike and lasting tens of time steps. Manifestation: abrupt drop to a deep negative plateau, typical valley amplitude ≈ -1.8 to -2.2, with small high-frequency micro-oscillations on top. Time-frequency: strong energy again concentrated at the lowest-frequency rows during the valley (reflecting large DC/low-frequency deviation) and some low-to-intermediate frequency energy from micro-oscillations. Heatmap mapping: predominantly red at the low-frequency rows during valley windows (model considers the valley a typical label feature). Occasional blue pixels in mid-frequency rows overlay the valley region in some samples (indicating that those particular frequency components are less typical or confuse the model), but the low-frequency red presence dominates → valley treated as typical overall.

Sustained negative plateau / slow oscillatory negative morphology (Sample 0, 4, 15, 93) - occurrence: roughly the immediate post-valley interval spanning ~t≈70..140 (sample-specific). Manifestation: low-frequency negative plateau near -2 with gentle (low-amplitude) slow oscillation and modest volatility (small random fluctuations). Time-frequency: continued energy in the very-low-frequency rows (0Hz and adjacent); slightly more energy spread into a band of low/mid-low frequency rows representing the slow oscillation. Heatmap mapping: mixture of red and scattered blue in these low-to-mid frequency rows during the plateau. In many samples low-frequency cells remain red (typical), while some intermediate rows show blue (indicative that certain oscillatory components in the plateau are ambiguous/atypical). Overall classification: mostly typical for the DC-like negative deviation, but with ambiguous mid-frequency components.

Slow recovery upward trend (gradual ramp) (Sample 0: t≈120..190; Sample 4: t≈130..200; Sample 15: t≈130..200; Sample 93: t≈140..220) - occurrence: mid-to-late phase. Manifestation: monotonic slow increase from the negative plateau back to near-zero and beyond, crossing y=0 in mid-to-late window and asymptoting toward the initial positive baseline (~+0.5). Morphology: sigmoid-like ramp with modest jitter. Time-frequency: energy concentrated at the lowest frequencies (trend) plus light mid-frequency energy where jitter/small oscillations occur. Heatmap mapping: mixed coloring — low-frequency trend cells sometimes red (model sees the overall ramp as typical), but many adjacent cells (especially where oscillatory components appear) are blue or mixed → model confusion or atypical contributions in those mid-frequency bands. Thus the trend's DC component is more typical while its oscillatory components are more ambiguous/atypical.

Late-stage stable return to baseline (Sample 0, 4, 15, 93) - occurrence: roughly t≈190..275. Manifestation: re-established positive baseline around +0.4..+0.6 with low volatility, similar to the start but slightly noisier. Time-frequency: low energy concentrated at 0Hz row and minimal upper-frequency energy. Heatmap mapping: generally neutral-to-mild red in lowest frequency rows (weak typical) and scattered light-blue pixels in higher rows (minor atypical frequency contributions). Classified as largely typical (baseline recovery), though the model assigns weaker importance here compared to the spike/valley windows.

Low-amplitude jitter / small high-frequency fluctuations superposed on plateau and recovery (all samples) - occurrence: throughout plateau and recovery phases. Manifestation: small, higher-frequency oscillations (visible as mild roughness). Time-frequency: higher relative energy at adjacent mid-frequency rows (not the 0Hz row) during windows where jitter is visible. Heatmap mapping: these mid-frequency cells are often blue or mixed (model considers these components atypical or confusing relative to the label). Classification: atypical features (blue) or ambiguous when mixed with low-frequency red.

Time-frequency concentration pattern (summary) - across samples the dominant T-F signature of the label is strong, concentrated low-frequency (0Hz row + adjacent lower rows) energy localized at the spike and valley time windows. Heatmap mapping: these concentrated low-frequency cells are repeatedly red (typical), which means the model relies on large low-frequency deviations (sharp spike + deep valley) as main label indicators. Adjacent higher-frequency spread, when present, is often blue/ambiguous.
pattern: Pattern for Sample 0 (index 0): Early stable positive baseline t≈0..50 (~+0.5) (low-freq weak red = typical) + Sudden short positive spike t≈55..62 (amplitude up to +3.7) (0Hz row strong red = typical) + Immediate deep negative valley t≈62..90 (amplitude ≈ -2.0) (0Hz row strong red = typical) + Sustained negative plateau with slow low-amplitude oscillation t≈70..140 (low-freq red + mid-freq mixed blue = typical DC deviation but ambiguous oscillatory components) + Slow monotonic recovery crossing y=0 around t≈145..170 (low-freq partly red, mid-freq mixed blue = trend typical, oscillations ambiguous) + Late stable baseline t≈190..275 (~+0.5) (low-freq mild red = typical).

Pattern for Sample 4 (index 4): Early stable baseline t≈0..55 (~+0.55) (low-freq light red = typical) + Sharp positive impulse t≈60..68 (peak ≈+3.8, 0Hz strong red = typical) + Rapid fall into deep negative valley t≈68..95 (≈-2.0, 0Hz strong red = typical) + Negative plateau with slow wave t≈80..140 (0Hz red, adjacent mid rows show blue/mixed = overall typical plateau, some atypical mid-frequency oscillations) + Gradual recovery ramp t≈140..200 crossing zero near t≈150..175 (low-frequency trend red but mid-freq oscillatory parts mixed/blue = trend typical, jitter atypical) + Final stabilization t≈200..275 (~+0.5) (low-freq weak red typical).

Pattern for Sample 15 (index 15): Early baseline t≈0..90 (~+0.58) (low-freq red = typical) + Very sharp spike t≈95..102 (peak ≈+3.8, 0Hz strong red = typical) + Immediate deep valley t≈102..130 (≈-2.1, low-freq strong red = typical) + Prolonged negative period t≈110..160 with slower return (low-freq red, some intermediate rows blue = predominant typical valley + ambiguous oscillatory components) + Slower ramp-to-baseline t≈160..220 (trend low-freq partly red but mixed heatmap above suggests model uncertainty on oscillatory detail) + Late approach to baseline t≈220..275 (~+0.5) (low-freq mild red typical).

Pattern for Sample 93 (index 93): Early mild-positive baseline t≈0..100 (~+0.65) (low-freq red = typical) + Prominent positive spike t≈100..108 (peak ≈+3.8, concentrated low-freq red = typical) + Downward plunge to valley t≈108..140 (≈-1.9 to -2.1, 0Hz red = typical) + Negative plateau with gradual oscillatory recovery t≈120..200 (low-frequency red dominant; mid-frequency contributions are mixed/blue → some atypical components) + Late-stage gradual recovery and re-stabilization t≈200..275 (low-freq mild red typical).

feature: Sample 1 - Pre-event baseline (baseline) (time ~0–~99): stable positive baseline around 0.60–0.80 (low volatility, small high-frequency noise ±0.05). In the STFT this maps to very low energy concentrated at the 0 Hz row and immediately adjacent low-frequency rows. SHAP/heatmap: predominantly RED coloring at the lowest frequency rows during the early window (small pockets of blue allowed) → interpreted as a typical baseline feature for this label (model expects a steady positive baseline prior to the transient).

Sample 1 - Abrupt negative step/drop (other/peak-negative) (time ~99–~106): steep, nearly vertical decline from ~+0.7 down to ~-2.0 to -2.2 (large magnitude change ≈ -2.7 to -3.0) occurring over very few time steps. STFT: a strong low-frequency / DC-energy burst at the time of the drop (high energy on 0 Hz row and immediate low-frequency rows); little spread into high frequencies (step-like). SHAP: strong RED signal concentrated at the 0 Hz row and adjacent low-frequency rows aligned with the drop → classified as a typical, highly discriminative feature.

Sample 1 - Deep valley / plateau (valley) (time ~106–~130): sustained low amplitude around -2.0 to -2.2 (relatively stable negative plateau with low jitter). STFT: continued elevated energy concentrated at 0 Hz band across this window. SHAP: mostly RED in the 0 Hz/low-frequency band across the valley window (with local minor blue pixels) → valley is a typical feature (model uses this DC negative excursion as label-characteristic).

Sample 1 - Gradual recovery / ramp (other/trend-change) (time ~130–~220): smooth, monotonic recovery from valley back toward positive values; crosses y=0 between ~180–200 and asymptotes around 0.6–0.7 by the end. STFT: low-frequency energy during the ramp (broad low-frequency content because of slow change) with limited high-frequency spread. SHAP: RED remains concentrated in low-frequency rows during much of the ramp (some mixed red/blue patches in adjacent bands) → recovery is generally considered a typical feature, though the model shows some ambiguity in portions of the ramp (mixed colors) where the slope shape varies.

Sample 1 - Late-stage stabilized baseline (baseline) (time ~220–~275): returns to pre-event positive baseline (~0.6–0.75) with low volatility. STFT: low energy concentrated at 0 Hz, minor noise. SHAP: low-frequency region near the late stage shows RED or neutral tones → considered typical (model expects eventual return to positive baseline).

Sample 1 - Small high-frequency jitter (other/noise) (throughout): tiny fast fluctuations superimposed on baseline and ramp (amplitude small ~0.05). STFT: tiny energy in higher-frequency rows but very small compared to DC. SHAP: these higher-frequency components show mixed red/blue scattered pixels (no dominant pattern) → interpreted as ambiguous/minor; not central to classification.

Sample 23 - Pre-event baseline (baseline) (time ~0–~60): stable positive baseline ~0.6–0.75 with low volatility; mapped to low-frequency energy in STFT (0 Hz). SHAP: low-frequency RED in early window (typical).

Sample 23 - Early abrupt drop (other/peak-negative) (time ~60–~66): very rapid step-like fall from ~+0.7 to about -2.15 to -2.25 (large amplitude negative spike). STFT: concentrated high energy at 0 Hz during drop, little high-frequency spread. SHAP: strong RED at the 0 Hz row coincident with the drop (typical feature).

Sample 23 - Sustained valley (valley) (time ~66–~120): negative plateau around -2.0 to -2.25 that slowly begins to trend upward. STFT: persistent DC/low-frequency energy. SHAP: RED dominance in the lowest frequency rows through the valley (typical).

Sample 23 - Recovery ramp and zero-crossing (other/trend-change) (time ~120–~180): monotonic rise, crosses y=0 around ~140–160, stabilizes near +0.6–0.7. STFT: low-frequency energy during ramp. SHAP: low-frequency region during recovery is RED-dominant but shows more mixed color pixels than the initial drop (still mainly typical but slightly more ambiguous in mid-ramp).

Sample 23 - Small mid-frequency contributions (other/ambiguity) (occasional): STFT shows slightly more adjacent low-frequency rows active around the time of the drop in this sample; SHAP in these adjacent rows presents a mixture of red and blue → these contributions are ambiguous (model partially confused whether adjacent low-frequency components are typical).
Sample 70 - Pre-event baseline (baseline) (time ~0–~74): stable positive baseline ~0.65–0.75. STFT: low DC energy. SHAP: RED at 0 Hz early → typical.

Sample 70 - Very sharp drop (other/peak-negative) (time ~74–~78): abrupt descent from ~+0.7 to ~-2.15 to -2.25 (extreme negative excursion over few steps). STFT: strong 0 Hz energy, some small spread into adjacent low-frequency rows (because of the transient). SHAP: RED concentrated at low frequency rows in the drop window → typical, high importance.

Sample 70 - Valley and slow monotonic increase (valley + trend-change) (time ~78–~150): valley ~-2.2 followed by an extended, fairly smooth ramp back toward positive values; zero crossing around ~150–165. STFT: low-frequency dominant energy across valley and ramp. SHAP: RED dominant at bottom 1–2 rows across the valley and early ramp; scattered blue/neutral pixels at higher rows → the core valley/ramp is typical; some higher-row ambiguity exists (not central).
Sample 70 - Late stabilization (baseline) (time ~180–~275): returns to ~0.6–0.7 stable. SHAP: low-frequency RED in later window consistent with typical behavior.
Sample 66 - Pre-event baseline (baseline) (time ~0–~98): stable ~0.65–0.8. STFT: DC/0 Hz energy. SHAP: RED at 0 Hz early (typical).

Sample 66 - Abrupt step/drop (other/peak-negative) (time ~98–~102): sharp negative jump from ~+0.75 down to ~-2.1 to -2.25. STFT: concentrated low-frequency energy, clear DC signature. SHAP: strong RED at the bottom frequency rows aligned with this drop → typical feature.
Sample 66 - Sustained deep valley (valley) (time ~102–~140): negative plateau around -2.15 to -2.25. STFT: sustained 0 Hz energy. SHAP: RED dominance in 0 Hz/adjacent rows (typical).

Sample 66 - Recovery ramp / zero-crossing (other/trend-change) (time ~140–~210): monotonic increase, crosses zero ~180–195 and stabilizes near original baseline. STFT: low-frequency energy broad during ramp. SHAP: RED in low-frequency rows across ramp but with some mixed pixels in adjacent rows (mostly typical).

Sample 66 - Minor high-frequency noise (other/noise) (throughout): small fast jitter superimposed; STFT shows small higher-frequency content; SHAP colors at higher rows are mixed red/blue → ambiguous/noisy contributions with low importance.
pattern: Sample 1 pattern: Pre-event stable positive baseline (0–~99) (~+0.6–0.8) (0 Hz RED → typical) + abrupt steep negative step at ~99–106 to a deep valley (~-2.0 to -2.2) (0 Hz strong RED → typical, highly discriminative) + sustained valley/plateau (~106–130) (0 Hz RED → typical) + slow monotonic recovery (~130–220) crossing zero ~180–200 (low-frequency RED with some mixed pixels → mainly typical but partially ambiguous in slope shape) + late-stage stabilization (~220–275) (~+0.6–0.7) (0 Hz RED → typical). Small HF jitter throughout (mixed SHAP → ambiguous/minor).

Sample 23 pattern: Stable positive baseline (0–~60) (~+0.6–0.75) (0 Hz RED → typical) + very early abrupt drop (~60–66) to deep valley (~-2.15 to -2.25) (0 Hz RED → typical) + extended valley (~66–120) (0 Hz RED → typical) + recovery ramp (~120–180) crossing zero ~140–160 (low-frequency RED, more mixed than drop → typical with some model uncertainty) + late stabilization (~180–275) (~+0.6) (0 Hz RED → typical). Occasional adjacent low-frequency row contributions (mixed red/blue) create small ambiguity.

Sample 70 pattern: Positive baseline (0–~74) (~+0.65–0.75) (0 Hz RED → typical) + very sharp drop (~74–78) to valley (~-2.15 to -2.25) (0 Hz RED and adjacent low-freq energy → typical) + prolonged negative valley and smooth ramp (~78–150) (dominant low-frequency energy; SHAP RED at 0 Hz → typical) + recovery and late stabilization (~150–275) (0 Hz RED → typical). Higher-frequency components are weak and SHAP shows mixed colors → not decisive.

Sample 66 pattern: Pre-event baseline (~0–98) (~+0.65–0.8) (0 Hz RED → typical) + abrupt drop (~98–102) to deep valley (~-2.1 to -2.25) (0 Hz RED → typical) + valley plateau (~102–140) (0 Hz RED → typical) + slow recovery (~140–210) crossing zero around ~180–195 (low-frequency RED mostly → typical) + late stabilized baseline (~210–275) (~+0.6–0.7) (0 Hz RED → typical). Minor HF jitter appears as mixed-color heatmap pixels and is treated as ambiguous/noise.

Cross-sample summary of patterns (explicitly shown in sample patterns above): each sample is composed of the same ordered sequence of features: (1) stable positive baseline at start (typical, low-frequency/red) → (2) an abrupt, step-like negative drop (very large negative amplitude) localized in time (typical, strong RED at 0 Hz) → (3) a sustained deep valley/plateau (typical, 0 Hz RED) → (4) a slow monotonically increasing recovery (low-frequency energy, mostly RED but with some mixed pixels indicating the model may be somewhat sensitive to the ramp shape) → (5) final stabilization back to original positive baseline (typical). High-frequency components are minimal and heatmaps show mixed red/blue there (ambiguous and of low importance).

feature: Sample 3 (index shown as Sample 3, Label 2) - Early baseline (0-60): persistent negative offset around -1.8 to -1.6 with low volatility (small random jitter). Time-frequency: almost all energy concentrated at the 0Hz / lowest-frequency row (very low-frequency content). Heatmap color: mostly weak red/neutral in the lowest-frequency row for early times (mixed small red/white) indicating the baseline is modestly typical for the label. Classification: typical low-frequency baseline feature (low-frequency red tendency).

Sample 3 - Step-up transition (approx. 60-100): rapid monotonic rising trend from negative baseline to a positive plateau; amplitude change ~2.0 units (from approx -1.8 to +0.6). Time-frequency: pronounced high energy in the lowest-frequency row during the transition window; energy slightly spreads to adjacent low-frequency rows (very narrow frequency band). Heatmap color: strong red concentrated on the 0Hz/lowest-frequency row at times ~99-149 (and rising window), indicating the step-up is a strongly typical feature for the label. Classification: typical feature (low-frequency, step/rise).

Sample 3 - Mid plateau (approx. 100-170): relatively stable positive amplitude around +0.55 to +0.7 with low volatility (small jitter). Time-frequency: low-energy (steady DC/low-freq signature) concentrated at lowest-frequency row. Heatmap color: low-to-moderate red/neutral at lowest frequencies in this window (typical/expected). Classification: typical stable plateau feature.

Sample 3 - Transient spike & valley (approx. 170-205): a sharp positive peak around ~+1.1 followed immediately by a deep drop (valley) to ~+0.05 then recover back to plateau ~+0.6; morphology is fast, high-amplitude, and asymmetrical (sharp up then deep dip). Time-frequency: strong energy concentrated in lowest-frequency row with increased spread into adjacent low-frequency rows (slightly broader frequency spread than step-up), indicating a faster transient. Heatmap color: mixed — lowest-frequency row near spike shows some red but adjacent low-frequency rows and times around the valley show blue patches. Classification: partially typical in DC row (red) but presence of blue in adjacent rows/time windows indicates the transient is partly atypical / ambiguous (model confuses spike/valley features with other labels).

Sample 16 (Label 2) - Early baseline (0-90): negative baseline ~-1.5 to -1.4 with moderate stability; slight jitter. Time-frequency: dominant low-frequency energy at 0Hz row. Heatmap: lowest-frequency row contains red markings especially around the later portion of the early window (typical baseline signature). Classification: typical.

Sample 16 - Step-up transition (approx. 95-130): rising slope crossing y=0 around ~100 and reaching plateau near +0.7; amplitude change approx 2.2 units. Time-frequency: strong energy at 0Hz row during rise, limited spread to adjacent low-frequency rows. Heatmap: strong red concentrated in bottom rows at mid times (99-149), indicating the rise is a strongly typical discriminative feature. Classification: typical.

Sample 16 - Mid plateau and pre-spike stability (approx. 130-185): stable around +0.7 with small jitter. Time-frequency: low-energy DC. Heatmap: predominantly red/neutral at lowest frequencies (typical).

Sample 16 - Sharp spike & valley (approx. 185-210): distinct positive spike to ~+1.2 then quick drop to around +0.25 before recovery. Time-frequency: increased energy at 0Hz plus slight energy in adjacent low-frequency bands. Heatmap: mixed but leans red on the lowest-frequency row and weak blue in neighboring low-frequency cells — interpreted as mostly typical at DC but with ambiguous/atypical contributions in higher low-frequency components. Classification: mostly typical in DC, ambiguous overall.

Sample 74 (Label 2) - Early baseline (0-40): deep negative baseline around -2.2 to -2.0 (deeper than other samples) with small jitter. Time-frequency: strong DC low-frequency energy. Heatmap: bottom row shows red around mid-times but early baseline exhibits mixed colors (some blue spots) indicating that a deeper baseline is present in the data but partially atypical compared to other label instances. Classification: baseline is largely typical at DC but the deeper magnitude introduces some atypical signatures (blue) in the heatmap.

Sample 74 - Fast step-up (approx. 50-85): rapid monotonic rise from about -2.0 to ~+0.5 (very large amplitude change ~2.5 units). Time-frequency: concentrated low-frequency energy with narrower spread; strong energy at the 0Hz row during transition. Heatmap: red concentrated in lowest-frequency row for the rise window (typical). Classification: typical step-up in DC band despite larger magnitude.
Sample 74 - Mid plateau (approx. 85-165): stable around +0.5 to +0.6 with small jitter. Time-frequency: dominant DC energy. Heatmap: mostly red/neutral in bottom cells (typical).

Sample 74 - Very sharp spike & valley (approx. 165-200): strong positive spike to ~+1.2 (narrow) then deep valley close to 0 or slightly negative, recovering to +0.5. Time-frequency: DC energy concentration but somewhat broader low-frequency spread (shorter-duration transient => slightly more high-frequency content). Heatmap: bottom row shows red at some spike times, but adjacent low-frequency rows and a few time blocks are blue indicating atypical contributions; overall mixture suggests ambiguity. Classification: mixed (typical at DC, atypical in adjacent low-frequency bands), model confusion present.

Sample 81 (Label 2) - Early baseline (0-80): negative baseline approx -1.6 to -1.5, low jitter. Time-frequency: DC-dominated. Heatmap: bottom-row red markings around mid-times (typical baseline signature), early times show mixed low-intensity coloring (neutral to slight red). Classification: typical baseline.

Sample 81 - Step-up transition (approx. 80-110): fairly rapid rise from negative to about +0.5–+0.7 (amplitude change ~2.1 units). Time-frequency: strong DC energy with a narrow low-frequency spread. Heatmap: strong red at lowest-frequency row during the step window and around times 99-149 (highly typical). Classification: typical step-up.
Sample 81 - Mid plateau (approx. 110-175): stable at +0.6–+0.75 with low volatility. Time-frequency: DC-dominated. Heatmap: red/neutral in lowest-frequency row (typical).

Sample 81 - Spike & shallow valley (approx. 175-205): single pronounced spike up to ~+1.2 followed by a drop to +0.25 and recovery. Time-frequency: increased low-frequency energy and slight spreading to neighboring bands. Heatmap: strong red at DC around pre-spike and spike center, but blue/neutral in adjacent rows at the valley — overall mixed. Classification: spike center typical at DC; valley and adjacent spectral components ambiguous/atypical.
pattern: Pattern for Sample 3: Early-stage deep negative baseline (0-60) (-1.8 to -1.6) (0Hz DC row red/neutral -> typical) + Mid-stage rapid step-up (60-100) (rise to +0.6, strong DC energy) (0Hz row red -> typical) + Plateau (100-170) (stable +0.55–+0.7, DC red/neutral -> typical) + Late transient (170-205) (sharp positive spike to +1.1 then valley to ~0.05 then recover) (DC row mixed red; adjacent low-frequency rows show blue -> spike center partly typical at DC but valley/adjacent frequencies ambiguous or atypical).

Pattern for Sample 16: Early negative baseline (0-90) (-1.5 to -1.4) (DC red -> typical) + Rapid rise (95-130) (cross y=0, plateau +0.7) (strong DC red -> typical) + Stable mid plateau (130-185) (+0.7, DC red -> typical) + Late spike & valley (185-210) (spike ~+1.2 then drop ~+0.25) (DC shows red, neighboring low-frequency cells present weak blue -> mostly typical at DC with ambiguous/atypical neighboring-frequency contributions).

Pattern for Sample 74: Early deeper negative baseline (0-40) (~-2.2 to -2.0) (DC energy present but heatmap shows mixed blue spots -> baseline magnitude partially atypical) + Very fast large-amplitude step-up (50-85) (rise to +0.5, amplitude change ~2.5) (0Hz red -> typical) + Stable mid plateau (85-165) (+0.5–+0.6, DC red -> typical) + Strong short spike & valley (165-200) (peak to ~+1.2 then near-zero valley) (DC row red but adjacent low-frequency rows blue -> mixed: typical at DC, atypical in adjacent frequency/time cells).

Pattern for Sample 81: Early baseline (0-80) (~-1.6 to -1.5, low jitter) (DC red/neutral -> typical) + Fast step-up (80-110) (rise to +0.6–+0.7; strong low-frequency energy) (0Hz red -> typical) + Mid plateau (110-175) (+0.6–+0.75 stable) (DC red -> typical) + Late spike & recovery (175-205) (sharp spike ~+1.2 then shallow valley ~+0.25 then recover) (heatmap: spike center DC red typical; valley and adjacent frequency cells show blue/neutral -> ambiguous/partially atypical).

feature: Sample 1 (Plot - Sample 2): Feature A - Early baseline (type: baseline/valley). Occurrence time: t≈0–50. Manifestation: steady negative baseline around -2.1 to -2.0 with low-amplitude Gaussian jitter (very low volatility). Time-frequency mapping: energy concentrated in the lowest frequency row (0 Hz row) and immediate adjacent low-frequency bins during this early window. Heatmap color: strong red concentrated on the 0Hz row at early time bins (bright red near t≈24 tick). Interpretation: typical feature (model considers this early stable deep-negative baseline a hallmark of the label). Feature B - Upward transition/trend change (type: other/trend-change). Occurrence time: t≈50–85. Manifestation: rapid, approximately monotonic rise from ~-2.0 up to ~+0.5 (large rate of change, steep slope), morphology = sigmoid/step-like increase with little oscillatory jitter. Time-frequency mapping: elevated energy still primarily in the lowest frequency rows (low-frequency band) localized in the transition time-window; little spread into higher frequencies (i.e., energy concentrated, not highly jittery). Heatmap color: mixed but with positive/red contributions in low-frequency rows near the transition and scattered low-magnitude blue/neutral in slightly higher rows. Interpretation: largely typical in the low-frequency components (red/typical at 0Hz band) but with some ambiguous/weak negative contributions in adjacent frequencies. Feature C - Late-stage positive plateau (type: baseline/peak). Occurrence time: t≈85–275. Manifestation: stable positive plateau around +0.45–+0.6 with small jitter; low volatility. Time-frequency mapping: low-frequency energy persists but magnitude lower than during transition; STFT shows dominant low-frequency energy at plateau times as well. Heatmap color: mostly weak red/neutral at low-frequency rows in the late stage, but scattered small blue cells across other frequency rows. Interpretation: plateau low-frequency signature is considered generally typical (weak red/neutral) but with ambiguous higher-frequency contributions (not strongly atypical).

Sample 2 (Plot - Sample 5): Feature A - Early baseline (type: baseline/valley). Occurrence time: t≈0–110. Manifestation: steady negative baseline around -1.25 to -1.15, low volatility with small noise. Time-frequency mapping: strong low-frequency energy at earliest bins (0Hz row strongest) and some elevated energy in adjacent low-frequency rows; STFT shows larger low-frequency magnitude at early times. Heatmap color: very pronounced red on the 0Hz row at early time bins (notably at the tick near t≈24) indicating positive SHAP contribution. Interpretation: typical feature (model strongly recognizes this early negative baseline in low-frequency band). Feature B - Sharp rising step (type: other/trend-change/peak). Occurrence time: t≈110–135. Manifestation: steep, large-amplitude rise crossing y=0 to reach a plateau near +0.9; morphology = sharp step with relatively short rise time. Time-frequency mapping: concentrated energy in low-frequency band during the rise, with some slightly broader spread than Sample 1 (slightly more adjacent low-frequency rows active). Heatmap color: low-frequency rows during the rise show patches of red/neutral; some intermediate frequency cells show light blue or mixed signs. Interpretation: low-frequency portion of the rise is typical (red/neutral), while scattered higher frequency contributions are ambiguous or weakly atypical. Feature C - High positive plateau (type: peak/stable). Occurrence time: t≈135–275. Manifestation: stable high positive plateau around +0.8–+1.0 with small jitter. Time-frequency mapping: low-frequency band remains dominant; STFT shows energy concentrated at bottom rows. Heatmap color: mostly neutral to weak red at 0Hz; other rows mixed. Interpretation: plateau low-frequency signature is treated as typical/neutral by the model, higher-frequency variations are ambiguous.

Sample 3 (Plot - Sample 29): Feature A - Early baseline (type: baseline/valley). Occurrence time: t≈0–95. Manifestation: steady negative baseline around -1.35 to -1.25 with small noise; low volatility overall. Time-frequency mapping: concentrated low-frequency energy (0Hz row) in early window; minimal high-frequency content. Heatmap color: distinct red at the bottom-most frequency around early time bins (bright red at ~t=24 tick). Interpretation: typical feature (model uses this early low-frequency negative baseline as a strong positive indicator). Feature B - Transition/rise (type: trend-change). Occurrence time: t≈95–125. Manifestation: sharp rise from ≈-1.3 to ≈+0.8 (steep slope), crossing y=0 near the start/middle of the rise; morphology: step-like. Time-frequency mapping: low-frequency energetic signature centered around transition; some small spread into adjacent low-frequency rows but not a strong high-frequency spread (little jitter). Heatmap color: low-frequency rows at the transition show mixed red/neutral cells; mid-frequency rows contain a mixture of weak red and blue indicating ambiguity in those components. Interpretation: low-frequency portion of transition typical; other components ambiguous. Feature C - Positive plateau (type: peak/stable). Occurrence time: t≈125–275. Manifestation: stable positive plateau around +0.7–+0.85 with low jitter. Time-frequency mapping: predominantly low-frequency energy; STFT low-row strong but lower than during rise. Heatmap color: bottom rows show light red/neutral; upper rows mixed. Interpretation: plateau typical at low-frequency band, ambiguous elsewhere.

Sample 4 (Plot - Sample 48): Feature A - Early baseline (type: baseline/valley). Occurrence time: t≈0–95. Manifestation: steady negative baseline around -1.35 to -1.25 with minimal jitter. Time-frequency mapping: strong low-frequency (0Hz) energy concentration during early phase; STFT shows pronounced bottom-row amplitude at early times. Heatmap color: clearly red at 0Hz early bins (strong red at tick near t≈24). Interpretation: typical feature. Feature B - Steep rising transition (type: trend-change). Occurrence time: t≈95–120. Manifestation: rapid increase ~-1.2 to ~+0.8, step-like with moderate slope; morphology consistent across samples (sharp monotonic change). Time-frequency mapping: concentrated low-frequency energy during transition; minimal high-frequency spread (indicating low jitter). Heatmap color: bottom rows around transition show light red/neutral; adjacent mid-frequency rows show scattered blue and light red (mixed). Interpretation: low-frequency transition is typical; mid-frequency contributions are ambiguous/weakly atypical in spots. Feature C - Late plateau (type: peak/stable). Occurrence time: t≈120–275. Manifestation: stable positive plateau ≈+0.7–+0.85 with low volatility. Time-frequency mapping: low-frequency energy persists but with smaller amplitude overall. Heatmap color: bottom band neutral to slightly red; higher bands mixed with occasional blue. Interpretation: typical in low-frequency band, ambiguous across other bands.
pattern: Pattern for Sample 1: Early-stage deep negative baseline (t≈0–50) at ~-2.0 (typical, red on 0Hz low-frequency row) + Middle-stage steep upward transition (t≈50–85) from -2.0 to +0.5 dominated by low-frequency energy (low-row red/neutral; model treats the low-frequency transition as typical but shows mixed responses in adjacent frequency rows) + Late-stage stable positive plateau (t≈85–275) at ≈+0.45–+0.6 with low jitter (low-frequency components weakly red/neutral, higher-frequency contributions mixed). Overall sample structure = stable deep negative baseline (typical) -> sharp low-frequency step (typical) -> stable positive plateau (typical/neutral).

Pattern for Sample 2: Extended early negative baseline (t≈0–110) at about -1.25 (typical, strong red at 0Hz in early bins) + Abrupt step-up (t≈110–135) to a high positive plateau (~+0.8–+1.0) dominated by low-frequency energy (rise window shows red at 0Hz and mixed cells in adjacent rows) + Late-stage high stable plateau (t≈135–275) with small jitter (low-frequency band neutral-to-red). Model emphasis: early negative baseline low-frequency energy is strongly typical; transition low-frequency energy also considered typical though higher-frequency components may be ambiguous/atypical in spots.

Pattern for Sample 3: Long negative baseline (t≈0–95) at ≈-1.3 (typical red at 0Hz) + Relatively concentrated transition (t≈95–125) steeply rising to ~+0.8 (low-frequency dominant and treated as typical at bottom rows; mixed signals in mid-frequency rows) + Late positive plateau (t≈125–275) stable around +0.7–+0.85 (low-frequency neutral/red). Pattern summary: early stable valley + sharp low-frequency step + stable plateau; typical signature dominated by low-frequency bottom-row red markings with ambiguous/mixed higher-frequency responses.

Pattern for Sample 4: Early deep negative baseline (t≈0–95) around -1.35 (typical: strong red at the 0Hz row early) + Quick rise (t≈95–120) step up to ~+0.8 (low-frequency band red/neutral in transition; some adjacent mid-frequency blue markings indicate model confusion for those components) + Late plateau (t≈120–275) stable positive ~+0.7 (low-frequency band remains typical/neutral). Pattern summary: consistent baseline->step->plateau sequence where the model relies primarily on the 0Hz low-frequency energy at early times and transition times (red = typical), while responses in mid/higher frequency rows are mixed and produce ambiguous or occasionally atypical contributions (blue spots).

feature: Baseline (early phase, t≈0–70): stable positive offset ~0.5–0.7 above y=0, low volatility. STFT: low energy except small DC/very-low-frequency content (0Hz row). Heatmap: mostly red in the lowest frequency rows around early times (0–70) in many samples -> interpreted by the model as a typical baseline feature for this label (typical).

Sharp positive peak / transient (peak at t≈65–80): large, narrow upward spike with amplitude rising to ≈+3.5 to +4.0 (peak magnitude varies across samples). Morphology: very fast rise and fall (impulsive-like). STFT: concentrated, high energy in the lowest frequency rows (0Hz and immediately adjacent low-frequency rows) at the spike time; little spread to high frequencies (so the spike has a strong low-frequency energy signature in these images). Heatmap: predominantly red in the low-frequency rows aligned with the spike time in multiple samples (sample-specific slight blue patches in some samples). Interpretation: spike itself is largely marked red -> treated as a typical feature (typical) but with small ambiguous indications in some samples.

Immediate deep valley / negative excursion (valley at t≈80–105): sharp transition from the positive spike into a deep negative valley with amplitude ≈-1.8 to -2.2. Morphology: abrupt downward step/valley following the spike; relatively wider than the spike. STFT: strong low-frequency energy concentrated across the same time window as the valley (dominant in DC/lowest-frequency bins). Heatmap: mixed — in most samples the 0Hz row corresponding to the valley shows red patches indicating that the valley is treated as a label-typical feature, but there are also localized blue cells (especially at slightly higher low-frequency rows or immediate boundary times) indicating atypical contributions. Classification interpretation: valley is predominantly typical but contains ambiguous/atypical components (mixed).

Long, slow recovery / monotonic rising trend (middle-to-late phase, t≈100–200): after the valley the signal shows a prolonged monotonic upward trend (roughly linear-like) that crosses y=0 at about t≈170–190 and continues to a late plateau. Morphology: low-frequency, slowly changing drift with low volatility (smooth). STFT: energy concentrated in the very-low-frequency band (0Hz row) across an extended time window; less energy at higher frequencies. Heatmap: often shows blue (atypical) or mixed blue/red in these middle-to-late low-frequency rows; many samples show the recovery period colored more blue than the early-phase spike/valley. Interpretation: this long drift is frequently marked as atypical by the model (atypical), and is a prime source of confusion because it contradicts or modifies the expected late-phase behavior for the true label.

Late plateau / steady state (late phase, t≈200–275): final values settle near +0.5–0.6 with low volatility. STFT: low energy concentrated at DC. Heatmap: generally weak color but tends to be blue or neutral in some samples, meaning the late steady-state is not strongly endorsed as a typical feature (ambiguous/atypical).

Frequency dispersion / jitter (throughout): minimal high-frequency jitter; STFT shows most energy confined to the 0Hz row and a few adjacent low-frequency rows. Heatmap: higher-frequency rows are mostly neutral or slightly blue; therefore high-frequency content is not a strong typical feature (ambiguous/weak). This limited frequency dispersion indicates morphological, not noisy, events.

Temporal coexistence of opposing contributions (feature interaction): in the same low-frequency time region (around the spike+valley) the heatmap shows both red (typical) and blue (atypical) cells in adjacent frequency rows/time bins — a localized mixed pattern. Interpretation: coexisting red/blue signatures in the same event make the model 'confused' locally (ambiguous).

Early baseline (t ≈ 0–70): stable positive offset around +0.55–+0.65, very low volatility. Heatmap: low-frequency (0 Hz row and adjacent lowest rows) marked red -> typical feature. (This matches the preliminary summary but is included here to place other atypical events in context.)

Very sharp positive transient / spike (t ≈ 72–90, peak at ≈ 85–95): narrow, high-amplitude impulsive peak rising to ≈ +3.7–+3.9. STFT: high energy concentrated at the 0 Hz row (DC / very-low-frequency) with some energy leaking into the immediately adjacent low-frequency rows. Heatmap mapping: the DC row at the spike window is strongly red (typical), but critically there is a localized, strong blue signature in the adjacent low-but-nonzero-frequency rows (appearing as a deep blue cell centered near the spike time and a small frequency above 0 Hz). Interpretation: the impulsive spike has two distinct frequency-contributions in the model’s view — a DC/very-low-frequency part that is typical for label 0 (red), and a small but pronounced adjacent low-frequency component that is atypical (blue). This atypical higher-low-frequency component at the time of the spike is not emphasized in the preliminary summary and is important because it creates local frequency-contrast at the same time window.

Immediate deep valley following the spike (t ≈ 96–110, valley minimum ≈ -2.0 to -2.2): abrupt, relatively wide negative excursion directly after the impulsive spike. STFT: concentrated low-frequency energy across the valley window. Heatmap mapping: predominantly red in the 0 Hz row during the valley (treated largely as typical) but neighboring low-frequency rows show mixed red/blue cells at the spike→valley boundary. Interpretation: the valley itself is mostly typical (red at DC) but its boundary to the spike contains mixed/ambiguous frequency contributions that increase classifier uncertainty — this partially duplicates the preliminary summary but is reiterated here to emphasize the precise time-frequency juxtaposition with the spike’s atypical low-frequency leakage.

Sharp spike→valley transition boundary (t ≈ 84–104): highly localized time window where opposing contributions coexist. Manifestation: across adjacent frequency rows and contiguous time bins the heatmap shows co-located red and blue cells (red on DC, blue on adjacent low-frequency rows). Interpretation: this opposing-sign / mixed-frequency pattern at the same short time window is a distinct, sample-specific source of ambiguity (the model sees both strong typical and strong atypical evidence at the same instant). This 'frequency-contrast at the impulse' detail is not described explicitly in the preliminary summary.

Long slow recovery / monotonic rising trend (t ≈ 110–200): smoothed, low-volatility monotonic rise from ≈ -2.0 up toward and across 0 (crossing ≈ 170–185) and then toward a late plateau. STFT: energy confined to the very-low-frequency/DC row across an extended time window (low-frequency drift). Heatmap mapping: this recovery interval is largely blue/atypical in the heatmap, but with temporal heterogeneity — early part of the recovery (≈110–130) contains small red/neutral low-frequency support while the middle-to-late recovery (≈130–200) is dominated by blue cells. Interpretation: the recovery is not uniformly atypical — the early portion retains some typical-support while the extended later portion is treated as atypical, creating a time-heterogeneous pattern that biases the model toward other classes. The preliminary summary notes the recovery being atypical but does not emphasize the sample-specific heterogeneity (initial red → extended blue) which affects the decision boundary.

Late plateau / steady state (t ≈ 200–275): final values ≈ +0.5–+0.6, low volatility. STFT: low DC energy; heatmap: neutral to mildly blue (ambiguous/weakly atypical). Interpretation: contributes only weakly to the decision; acts as a secondary atypical signal in combination with the extended recovery.

Frequency dispersion / jitter (throughout): minimal high-frequency jitter overall; most energy at DC. However, the key sample-specific point is a narrow leakage of energy into adjacent low-frequency rows at the time of the spike (described above) — this small dispersion is marked blue and is disproportionately important for the classifier's shift in this sample.
pattern: Sample 19 (ID 19) pattern: Baseline early phase (t≈0–70) stable +0.55 (red in low-frequency heatmap = typical) + Sharp positive spike (t≈72–88) amplitude ≈+3.8 (red at 0Hz row = typical) + Immediate deep valley (t≈90–105) amplitude ≈-2.1 (low-frequency heatmap largely red but with localized blue cells = mixed/partly atypical) + Long slow recovery rising trend (t≈110–200) crossing y=0 near t≈180 (heatmap shows more blue in this interval = atypical) + Late plateau (t≈200–275) around +0.5 (weak blue/neutral = ambiguous). Model result: true label 0 (target) but predicted label 1 (logits [1.707, 1.900, -2.166, -1.691] -> class 1 maximized). Interpretation: the model receives strong early-phase 0Hz energy interpreted as typical for label 0 (red), but the extended slow recovery and some atypical low-frequency contributions (blue) during mid-to-late phase shift the decision toward class 1. The mixed red/blue at the valley boundary increases confusion leading to misclassification.

Sample 37 (ID 37) pattern: Early baseline (t≈0–70) +0.60 stable (red at 0Hz = typical) + Very sharp positive spike (t≈70–78) amplitude ≈+3.8 (red at lowest-frequency rows = typical) + Pronounced negative valley (t≈79–95) amplitude ≈-2.0 (low-frequency heatmap shows red dominance but several adjacent low-frequency rows show blue = mixed) + Slow monotonic recovery (t≈100–200) crossing zero near t≈175 (heatmap in this phase shows stronger blue patches = atypical) + Late steady state (t>200) ~+0.6 (neutral/weak blue = ambiguous). Model result: predicted 1 (logits [1.853, 2.064, -2.035, -1.702]). Interpretation: the coexistence of a prototypical early spike/valley and a later-phase atypical slow recovery produces a boundary pattern — the model elevates class 1 score because the mid/late low-frequency trend is more consistent with class-1 decision boundaries in training (atypical for label 0), despite early red support.

Sample 46 (ID 46) pattern: Baseline early (t≈0–50) ~+0.65 (red = typical) + Positive transient (t≈45–52) amplitude ≈+3.9 (narrow, very impulsive; STFT strong at 0Hz; heatmap red in 0Hz low rows = typical) + Deep valley (t≈52–85) amplitude ≈-2.0 (low-frequency energy; heatmap predominantly red in lowest rows but some red-blue mix higher = mostly typical/mixed) + Extended upward drift (t≈90–160) crosses y=0 around t≈145 (heatmap shows more diffuse red/blue with visible blue in adjacent low-frequency rows = ambiguous/atypical) + Final plateau t>200 ~+0.55 (neutral/weak blue). Model result: predicted 1 (logits [1.857, 1.882, -1.521, -1.444]). Interpretation: similar boundary composition — strong early features favor label 0 but the long recovery morphology (duration and crossing time) is atypical and drives the model toward class 1.

Sample 55 (ID 55) pattern: Early baseline (t≈0–70) ~+0.5 (red = typical) + Very narrow tall spike (t≈70–76) amplitude ≈+3.8–3.9 (STFT concentrated at 0Hz; heatmap low-frequency red = typical) + Sharp negative valley immediately after (t≈77–95) amplitude ≈-2.1 (low-frequency; heatmap red at DC but adjacent low-frequency cells show blue = mixed) + Smooth long recovery (t≈100–200) crossing y=0 around t≈170–180 (heatmap low-frequency rows mostly blue/neutral during recovery = atypical) + Late plateau (t>200) ~+0.55 (weak/ambiguous). Model result: predicted 1 (logits [1.780, 2.026, -1.948, -1.673]). Interpretation: as with other samples, the combination of a prototypical impulsive spike/valley (red) and a prolonged atypical recovery (blue) forms a boundary pattern that the black-box model resolves in favor of class 1. The mixed red/blue cells at the spike-to-valley boundary increase model uncertainty and contribute to misclassification.

Pattern A (true label 0 → misclassified as label 1): Early stable positive baseline (t 0–70) (offset ≈ +0.55–+0.65) (red at 0 Hz = typical) + Very sharp impulsive spike (t 72–90) (narrow, amplitude ≈ +3.8) with DC energy strongly red (typical) BUT simultaneous localized atypical contribution in adjacent low-frequency rows at the spike time (blue at low-nonzero-frequency row = atypical) (this frequency-contrast at the impulse increases ambiguity) + Immediate deep negative valley (t 96–110) (amplitude ≈ -2.0 to -2.2) (0 Hz mostly red but adjacent low-freq mixed = mostly typical/mixed) + Long, non-oscillatory monotonic recovery (t 110–200) (smooth rise crossing 0 at ≈170–185) (early recovery bins show small red/neutral contributions but middle-to-late recovery dominated by blue at DC = atypical) + Late weak plateau (t 200–275) (≈+0.5) (neutral/light-blue = ambiguous). Black-box logits: class0 logit 1.707 vs class1 logit 1.900 (class1 wins by ≈0.19), indicating the atypical mid/late low-frequency recovery plus the spike’s adjacent low-frequency blue leakage together shift the decision boundary toward label 1 despite strong early red support for label 0.

Summary of boundary-driving factors (derived from Pattern A): (1) Coexistence of strongly typical DC energy at the spike/valley and a localized atypical adjacent low-frequency component at the exact spike time (time-frequency contrast) — this creates a direct conflict in the classifier’s attributions. (2) Extended slow recovery that is temporally heterogeneous: small pockets of red/neutral early in the recovery followed by a sustained blue-dominated recovery window — the duration and timing of the blue-dominant recovery are highly influential. (3) The combination of (1) and (2) produces a small margin between class 0 and class 1 logits (≈0.19), producing a boundary sample that is easily tipped by these atypical low-frequency signatures.

feature: Baseline (early phase, t ≈ 0–100): baseline type. Manifestation: steady positive level roughly between +0.6 and +0.9 with low variance (small noise/jitter). STFT: low energy concentrated at the 0 Hz row and very low-frequency bins. Heatmap color: mostly pale / light-red at the 0Hz row with scattered neutral cells in higher rows. Interpretation: ambiguous/weakly-typical feature — provides modest evidence for the class but by itself is not decisive.

Sharp negative step / Valley onset (transition, t ≈ 110–130): valley type. Manifestation: abrupt, large-magnitude drop from the positive baseline to a deep trough (drop magnitude ≈ 2.5–3.0 units, from ~+0.8 down to ≈ -2.0). Morphology: very steep slope (fast change), then an immediate low-amplitude jitter around the trough bottom. STFT: concentrated, high energy in the low-frequency row (0 Hz) and adjacent lowest-frequency bins localized in the same time window. Heatmap color: strong red concentrated at the 0 Hz row around the step (clear red spike) and red in adjacent low-frequency rows. Interpretation: typical feature for the target label (model treats this valley/step as a hallmark); this is the strongest single indicator in these samples.

Sustained deep trough (mid phase, t ≈ 125–160): valley / baseline type. Manifestation: prolonged negative values around -2.0 to -1.7 with low-amplitude jitter superimposed (stable trough). STFT: continued low-frequency dominance with slightly extended time support (energy remains in 0Hz row and immediate neighbors). Heatmap color: largely red in the lowest frequency components but mixed (some neighboring cells have neutral or slightly blue values). Interpretation: mostly typical but with some ambiguity — the sustained negative level mostly supports the label but small mixed heatmap signs hint at confusion.

Gradual recovery ramp (late phase, t ≈ 160–275): trend / other type. Manifestation: slow monotonic rise from trough back to positive values (crosses y=0 near t ≈ 220–235) ending near the original baseline (~+0.6–0.8). The slope is gradual (low instantaneous frequency content) and spans a long time window. STFT: low-frequency energy concentrated over an extended time, but because the change is slow the energy spreads into adjacent low-mid frequency bins (not only the 0Hz row). Heatmap color: mixed to blue in some of the low-mid frequency rows during the recovery interval (patches of blue / neutral in rows above 0Hz). Interpretation: atypical feature for the true label (the model marks portions of the recovery as evidence against the label, producing confusion).

Edge-region frequency spread (around the step edges, t ≈ 100–150): other. Manifestation: because the step is abrupt, the step edges produce small higher-frequency components (briefly). STFT: localized higher-frequency content adjacent to the step time-slices (though amplitude is much smaller than the main low-frequency energy). Heatmap color: scattered small blue and red cells in higher-frequency rows around the step. Interpretation: ambiguous — contributes noise to the decision boundary and can nudge classification depending on relative weighting.

Small high-frequency jitters (throughout the trace): other/noise type. Manifestation: low-amplitude high-frequency oscillations (visible as small jagged deviations on top of baseline and trough). STFT: weak high-frequency energy across many time steps. Heatmap color: small scattered blue and pale-red spots in higher-frequency rows. Interpretation: ambiguous/atypical depending on location; generally low influence but in combination with other features can increase model uncertainty.

Confirmation that preliminary summary covers the main events, followed by a detailed, stepwise feature extraction and mapping to heatmap/STFT/plot for Sample 52: 

Overview & baseline (t ≈ 0–110): The trace begins with a stable positive baseline around +0.6 to +0.9 with only small amplitude jitter. In the STFT this corresponds to concentrated energy at the lowest frequency row (0 Hz) and negligible higher-frequency content. The SHAP heatmap shows mostly pale-red cells in the 0 Hz row during this early window, indicating that the model treats the early positive baseline as weakly supportive (typical but low evidence) for the target label. Manifestation: stable amplitude, low variance, typical (red/pale-red) at 0 Hz.

Abrupt negative step / valley onset (t ≈ 110–130): A very sharp, large-magnitude drop occurs (~2.5–3.0 units drop from ~+0.8 down to ≈ -2.0). In the STFT this time window shows a concentrated high-energy patch strongly localized in the 0 Hz row and the adjacent lowest-frequency bins (clear high magnitude centered around the step). The SHAP heatmap shows strong red in the lowest-frequency row (and some red in adjacent low-frequency rows) aligned with the step time-slices. Interpretation: this valley/step is a canonical, strongly-typical feature for the true label (model uses it as primary supporting evidence). Manifestation: very steep slope, large magnitude trough bottom, typical (red) at 0 Hz and immediate neighbors.

Sustained deep trough / mid-phase (t ≈ 125–165): After the step the signal settles into a prolonged negative trough around -2.0 to -1.7 with low-amplitude jitter. The STFT maintains strong low-frequency energy over an extended time (still concentrated near 0 Hz but slightly extended in time support). SHAP here remains predominantly red in the lowest-frequency rows but with some mixed/neutral cells — overall mostly-typical but with slight ambiguity. Manifestation: stable negative baseline, low variance; typical/mostly-typical (red with minor mixed cells) at low freq.

Gradual recovery ramp / late-phase (t ≈ 165–275): The trace exhibits a slow, monotonic recovery from the trough back to positive values, crossing y=0 about t ≈ 220–235 and ending near the original baseline (~+0.6–0.8). STFT energy during this ramp is still concentrated at low frequencies but spreads into adjacent low-to-mid frequency bins because the change is slow (long time support → low-mid frequency content). The SHAP heatmap shows mixed-to-blue markings in the low–mid frequency rows during this interval — patches of blue indicating the model treats parts of the recovery ramp as atypical for the true label. Manifestation: long-duration trend/recovery, low instantaneous frequency but broader low-mid frequency footprint; atypical (blue/mixed) in low-mid frequency rows.

Edge-region higher-frequency spread (around the step edges, t ≈ 100–150): The abruptness of the step produces brief higher-frequency energy localized around the edges in the STFT. The SHAP map shows scattered small blue and pale-red cells in higher-frequency rows near the step, indicating ambiguity/noise in how those high-frequency components are interpreted (they slightly modulate classification but are weaker than the 0 Hz pattern). Manifestation: short-duration HF content adjacent to step; ambiguous (mixed small red/blue) in higher-frequency rows.

Small high-frequency jitters (throughout): Low-amplitude high-frequency jitter is visible across the trace (especially on baseline and trough edges). STFT shows weak HF energy spread; SHAP indicates small scattered blue/pale-red spots in HF rows. These are low-impact but contribute to model uncertainty when combined with competing evidence. Manifestation: small-amplitude HF oscillations; ambiguous/low influence (mixed blue/pale-red).
pattern: Pattern for Sample 38 (ID 38): True label = 1; Model predicted = 0. Pattern composition: Early steady positive baseline (t ≈ 0–100) (baseline, +0.6 to +0.9) (pale/light-red in heatmap at 0Hz => weakly-typical) + Rapid sharp negative step/valley (t ≈ 110–130) (valley, abrupt drop ≈ -2.8 magnitude) (strong red at 0Hz and adjacent low-frequency rows => typical) + Sustained deep trough (t ≈ 125–160) (valley/baseline, ≈ -2.0 sustained) (mostly red low-frequency, some mixed cells => mostly-typical with slight ambiguity) + Long gradual recovery ramp (t ≈ 160–275) (trend, monotonic rise crossing 0 near 220–235) (mixed/blue in low-mid frequency rows on heatmap => atypical). Model result & reflection: predicted label 0; logits [2.1579, 1.9282, -2.0277, -1.5825] show class 0 preferred but class 1 score close (margin ≈ 0.23), indicating borderline/confusing evidence. Cause of misclassification: the sample contains the key typical valley for label 1, but the long recovery ramp produces atypical low-mid frequency energy (blue/mixed heatmap) that reduces net support for label 1 and tips the model to class 0.

Pattern for Sample 52 (ID 52): True label = 1; Model predicted = 0. Pattern composition: Early steady positive baseline (t ≈ 0–110) (baseline, +0.6 to +0.9) (pale/light-red at low freq => weak support) + Sharp negative step/valley (t ≈ 115–130) (valley, abrupt drop to ≈ -2.0) (strong red at 0Hz => typical) + Sustained trough (t ≈ 125–165) (valley, ≈ -2.0 stable, small jitter) (predominantly red in lowest frequencies with a few neutral cells => typical/mostly-typical) + Extended recovery ramp (t ≈ 165–275) (trend, slow monotonic increase crossing zero ~220+) (heatmap shows mixed-to-blue low-mid freq contributions => atypical). Model result & reflection: predicted label 0; logits [2.0297, 1.9653, -1.9969, -1.5016] show a very small margin (class 0 vs class 1 difference ≈ 0.064), indicating this is a near-boundary case. The recovery ramp (atypical low-mid frequency energy) is the principal factor that counteracts the otherwise typical valley evidence and yields misclassification.

Pattern for Sample 75 (ID 75): True label = 1; Model predicted = 0. Pattern composition: Early positive baseline (t ≈ 0–110) (+0.6–+0.9) (pale/light-red at 0Hz => weakly-typical) + Very sharp negative step/valley (t ≈ 115–130) (drop to ≈ -2.0; abrupt with bottom jitter) (strong red at 0Hz => typical) + Stable deep trough (t ≈ 125–160) (≈ -2.0, small jitter) (mostly red low-frequency, minor mixed cells => typical) + Long, smooth recovery ramp (t ≈ 160–275) (slow rise crossing zero ~220–235) (heatmap: mixed with noticeable blue patches in low-mid frequency rows during the ramp => atypical). Model result & reflection: predicted label 0; logits [1.9865, 1.9431, -2.0119, -1.5034] show an extremely narrow margin (class0 vs class1 ≈ 0.043), making this a classic boundary sample. The presence of a canonical valley (typical) combined with an extended recovery trend (marked atypical by SHAP) creates competing evidence and leads to misclassification.

Overall reflection on why these patterns cause misclassification: In all three samples the dominant, strongly-typical event for label 1 is the abrupt large negative step and the deep trough (clear red at the 0Hz row in heatmaps and high energy in the STFT low-frequency band). However, each sample also contains a prolonged recovery/trend (slow ramp back to baseline) whose frequency signature spreads into low-mid frequency bins and is marked as mixed or blue in the heatmaps. That atypical recovery pattern reduces the net support for label 1 and introduces evidence toward another class, producing a small logit margin and therefore misclassification. Thus, boundary samples are produced by the co-occurrence of a strong typical valley event plus an extended/atypical recovery trend that the model treats as conflicting evidence.

Pattern (Sample 52) — True label = 1, Model predicted = 0 (logits: class0 2.0297, class1 1.9653; class0 preferred by margin ≈ 0.064): 

Pattern composition and contribution to boundary decision: 
- Stage A (Early, t ≈ 0–110): Positive baseline (+0.6 to +0.9), low variance. Heatmap: pale-red at 0 Hz → weakly-typical, modest support for class 1. 
- Stage B (Transition, t ≈ 110–130): Very sharp negative step (~-2.0 trough), high STFT energy concentrated at 0 Hz and nearest low-frequency bins. Heatmap: strong red at 0 Hz → strong, decisive evidence for class 1. 
- Stage C (Mid, t ≈ 125–165): Sustained trough (~-2.0), stable low-frequency energy. Heatmap: predominantly red with some neutral cells → mostly-typical, continues to support class 1. 
- Stage D (Late recovery, t ≈ 165–275): Long, smooth recovery ramp crossing zero ~220–235. STFT: low-frequency energy spreads into adjacent low–mid frequency bands. Heatmap: mixed-to-blue in low–mid rows during the ramp → atypical for class 1 and instead provides counter-evidence, pulling the net score away from class 1. 
- Auxiliary components: brief HF energy at step edges and small HF jitters throughout (ambiguous mixed markings) that increase uncertainty but do not dominate classification.

Why this is a boundary/misclassification: the sample contains the canonical valley signature (Stages B & C) which strongly favors class 1, but the extended recovery ramp (Stage D) is marked as atypical (blue/mixed) by the model and supplies opposing evidence. The near-equal logits and tiny margin indicate these competing contributions nearly cancel, and the atypical recovery is sufficient to tip the model toward class 0. 

Conclusion about preliminary summary coverage: the preliminary feature summary already enumerates all of these events (baseline, sharp negative step, sustained trough, long recovery ramp, edge HF spread, small HF jitters) and correctly identifies the recovery ramp as the primary atypical/contradictory feature that produces the classification boundary behavior. Therefore the preliminary summary covers the misclassification-causing features and patterns for Sample 52.

feature: Baseline (early phase, type: baseline) (occurrence time ~0-60): persistent negative offset before the main step change. Manifestation: stable low-level baseline values in the range approx. -1.5 to -2.2 (sample variation), low short-term volatility, little high-frequency jitter. Time-frequency mapping: concentrated energy at the 0 Hz / lowest-frequency row during this period. Heatmap color: mostly light-red to red at the 0Hz row in the transition-adjacent time bins (model marks DC-level as typical for the label in some regions) but occasionally neutral/weak elsewhere. Interpretation: baseline magnitude is an important low-frequency/DC feature; when larger-than-expected negative baseline occurs it is sometimes treated as typical (red at 0Hz) but can interact with other events to confuse the model.

Steep rising edge / step change (early-to-middle phase, type: other/peak-like transition) (occurrence time ~50-100 depending on sample): a rapid upward transition from the negative baseline to a positive plateau. Manifestation: sharp slope occurring over ~10-40 time steps, amplitude change ~1.5-2.2 (difference baseline -> plateau), relatively stable plateau after transition. Time-frequency mapping: strong low-frequency (0Hz row and adjacent lower rows) energy concentrated at the transition time; little high-frequency spread (transition is mostly low-frequency DC shift). Heatmap color: predominantly red at 0Hz and adjacent low-frequency rows for the transition bins (model treats the rising step as a typical class feature in many samples).

Middle/late positive transient spike (type: peak) (occurrence time ~150-210; sample dependent): a short-lived positive spike rising above the plateau (amplitude relative to plateau ~+0.3 to +0.5, absolute peak reaching ~0.8-1.2 in some samples). Manifestation: a narrow positive excursion (sharp rise then rapid fall). Time-frequency mapping: localized low-frequency energy at 0Hz and slightly increased energy in adjacent low-frequency rows; if the spike contains jitter it produces broader frequency spread. Heatmap color: mixed — shows red in some low-frequency bins but also blue or neutral cells in adjacent frequency rows and adjacent time bins. Interpretation: the presence of this spike is ambiguous — the model sometimes treats components of it as typical but parts as atypical, making it a confusion-inducing feature.

Immediate following sharp valley / trough (type: valley) (occurrence time ~160-225 depending on sample): a rapid negative deviation immediately after or overlapping the spike (magnitude drop to near 0 or below, relative change ~-0.3 to -0.6 from plateau). Manifestation: sharp dip following spike; momentary approach to or below the y=0 reference in some samples (where plateau is ~0.5-0.8). Time-frequency mapping: low-frequency energy localized at the same time bins as the spike but often showing opposite sign in waveform; occasionally small higher-frequency content if oscillatory. Heatmap color: often blue at some low-frequency rows and mixed colors in nearby rows/time bins (model marks these as atypical or confusing features).

Low-amplitude jitter / high-frequency noise around transitions (type: other / volatility) (occurrence time scattered around transition and spike times): small-scale variations superimposed on step and spike events. Manifestation: increased local volatility, small oscillations, frequency spread in STFT across several rows (higher-than-DC frequencies). Time-frequency mapping: energy spread across adjacent frequency rows (beyond pure 0Hz). Heatmap color: often neutral to blue in the mid/high-frequency rows (model treats these high-frequency components as atypical or non-characteristic), contributing to ambiguity in classification.
pattern: Sample ID 0 (true label: 2, misclassified as: 3, model logits: [-1.76, -2.26, 1.84, 1.91], predicted=3): Pattern = Early strong negative baseline (~-1.3 to -1.6) (baseline, time 0-100) (heatmap: red at 0Hz → model-considered typical) + pronounced step/rising edge around time ~100-125 (step magnitude ~1.8) (other, heatmap: red at 0Hz → typical) + middle-late positive transient spike at ~200-210 (peak amplitude above plateau ~0.3-0.5) immediately followed by a sharp valley/dip around ~210-225 (valley, heatmap: mixed red/blue at low freq and some blue in adjacent rows → ambiguous/atypical). The SHAP heatmap shows strongest red concentration at the earliest transition/DC bins and mixed colors around the spike/dip. The model’s logits show similar support for class 2 and class 3 (positive logits for both, slightly higher for class 3), indicating the spike+dip ambiguity pushes the sample across the decision boundary toward class 3.

Sample ID 2 (true label: 2, misclassified as: 3, model logits: [-1.82, -2.44, 1.78, 2.21], predicted=3): Pattern = Deep negative baseline (~-2.1 to -2.2) (baseline, time 0-60) (heatmap: red at low-frequency/DC but with stronger magnitude → typical) + earlier and sharper step-up around time ~60-80 (rapid slope, large amplitude change ~2.4) (other, heatmap: red at 0Hz → typical) + pronounced mid-sequence spike at ~160 then an abrupt trough reaching near zero around ~170-180 (peak+valley pair, heatmap: mixed — red in some DC cells but more blue/neutral in frequency rows around the trough → atypical). The late spike/trough sequence is the main ambiguous element; because the model’s logit for class 3 is highest, the trough part likely resembles features associated with class 3 in training data, producing misclassification.

Sample ID 5 (true label: 2, misclassified as: 3, model logits: [-1.77, -2.56, 1.88, 2.20], predicted=3): Pattern = Negative baseline (~-1.9 to -2.0) (baseline, time 0-70) (heatmap: red at 0Hz → typical) + clear transition/step at ~70-90 to stable plateau (~+0.5 to +0.6) (other, heatmap: red at 0Hz) + late large transient peak at ~160-180 (peak amplitude above plateau ~0.4-0.6) quickly followed by a deep valley close to y=0 at ~180-200 (valley, heatmap: shows red at DC for some bins but many blue cells across nearby frequencies/time → ambiguous/atypical). Small jitter energy around the spike spreads to higher frequency rows (heatmap: blue/neutral), increasing classification uncertainty. The model’s logits favor class 3 strongly over class 2 suggesting the spike+valley signature is being interpreted as class-3-like.

Sample ID 10 (true label: 2, misclassified as: 3, model logits: [-1.72, -2.56, 1.84, 2.14], predicted=3): Pattern = Negative baseline (approx. -1.6 to -1.8) early (baseline, 0-80) (heatmap: red at DC low-frequency bins) + somewhat later steep step-up (time ~80-100) to plateau (~+0.6) (other, heatmap: low-freq red) + late-time sharp positive spike around 210 (peak) followed by fast valley around 220 (valley) — the spike magnitude above plateau ~0.4 and the valley drops markedly toward 0. Time-frequency: spike/valley show low-frequency energy and small spread; SHAP: low-frequency early transition bins red but the late spike/valley bins show red at DC mixed with blue at adjacent freq rows (ambiguous). The logits show the model prefers class 3; the late spike+trough pattern likely resembles class-3 training examples or otherwise interferes with the class-2 signature making this a boundary case.

Reflection across samples: in all four boundary examples the core pattern is identical in structure: a stable negative baseline, a large early-to-mid DC step-up to a positive plateau (these two elements are typically marked red in the heatmaps at 0Hz and are characteristic of label 2), plus a later short transient peak immediately followed by a sharp valley/trough (the spike+valley is the recurring ambiguous/atypical event). The SHAP/heatmap evidence shows the early baseline and step are treated as typical (red at 0Hz), whereas the late transient spike+valley produce mixed red/blue indications (often blue in some low-frequency rows) — this mixed marking correlates with the model’s flip from class-2 to class-3 (logits show similar positive support for class-2 and class-3 but class-3 slightly higher), indicating that the spike+valley signatures are classification boundary features that push otherwise-typical label-2 traces into the model’s class-3 decision region.

Detailed analysis and justification that the preliminary summary already covers the boundary-causing features for Sample 2 (long-form explanation):

Overview and mapping of visible events
- Baseline (early stage, time ~0–60): The trace shows a persistent, steady negative offset around -2.0 to -2.2 in the first ~50–60 time steps with very low short-term volatility. This corresponds to strong DC content in the STFT (0 Hz row) and the SHAP heatmap shows consistent red contributions in the lowest-frequency rows during the early window. The baseline magnitude and stability are therefore treated by the model as a characteristic (typical) feature for the label. 

- Steep rising edge / step change (early→mid stage, time ~60–80): There is a relatively rapid, large-amplitude step from the negative baseline up to a positive plateau (~+0.45–+0.6). The slope happens over a few tens of time steps (visible sharp slope in the waveform), producing concentrated energy at the DC/lowest-frequency rows in the STFT. The SHAP heatmap shows red at those low-frequency time bins for this transition, indicating the model interprets that DC-level step as a typical class feature. The plateau after the step is fairly stable, again dominated by low-frequency energy and interpreted as typical.

- Middle/late positive transient spike (time ~150–165): A short-lived positive spike rises above the plateau (amplitude roughly +0.3–+0.5 relative to the plateau, absolute ~0.9–1.0 at the peak). In the STFT this appears as a local low-frequency energy increase, but noticeably less concentrated than the step (the spike is briefer). In the SHAP heatmap, the time-frequency cells around the spike show mixed coloration: some low-frequency bins are red while adjacent low- and mid-frequency bins show neutral-to-blue values. This indicates the model is uncertain about whether components of the spike are typical or atypical for the label.

- Immediate following sharp valley / trough (time ~165–180): Immediately after the spike there is a deep, fast negative trough that approaches or reaches the y=0 reference (relative drop ~-0.4 to -0.6 from plateau). The STFT shows localized energy here but with slightly different spectral spread (the abrupt polarity change creates energy in neighboring low-frequency rows). In the SHAP heatmap those late-time low-frequency bins are mixed with a substantial amount of blue (atypical) marking—especially at some DC-adjacent rows and some neighboring time bins. This suggests the trough contains features the model associates more with other labels (not the canonical label-2 signature).

- Low-amplitude jitter / higher-frequency spread (around transitions and spike/trough): Small oscillations are visible on the plateau and superimposed on the spike/trough which create weak energy in adjacent higher-frequency STFT rows. The SHAP heatmap marks many of these higher-frequency components as neutral/blue (atypical), further contributing to ambiguity.

Why this becomes a boundary sample (relation to logits)
- The model logits show competing support: class-2 has positive logit (~+1.78) but class-3 is higher (~+2.21). The SHAP evidence explains this: early baseline + DC step are strongly characteristic of class-2 (red in the DC heatmap cells) and pull the model toward class-2. However, the late spike+trough region has mixed/blue SHAP contributions in the relevant low-frequency rows (and some blue in adjacent frequency rows due to jitter). The trough portion in particular has properties (timing, polarity and spectral spread) that resemble class-3-like patterns in the training data, so the late atypical region counteracts the early typical evidence and tips the net score toward class-3.

Which specific features are the classification-boundary drivers
- The spike+immediate trough pair is the decisive ambiguous pattern. Its polarity reversal, peak/trough amplitudes and short duration produce spectral content that is mixed in the SHAP map (red + blue) — this overlap is exactly what moves the trace across the decision boundary.
- Secondary driver: small high-frequency jitter during the transient spreads energy into frequency rows that the model marks blue, increasing ambiguity.

Conclusion on preliminary summary coverage
- The provided preliminary feature summary already lists the baseline, the steep rising step, the late positive spike, the immediate valley and the localized jitter/high-frequency spread — and it notes that the spike/trough is ambiguous and causes confusion. All material boundary-causing features observed in the plot, STFT and SHAP heatmap for Sample 2 are included in that summary. Therefore there are no additional missing features or novel patterns to add beyond what is already documented in the preliminary summary.
